# Marginal product of labor

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

In economics, the **marginal product of labor** (**MP L**) is the change in
output that results from employing an added unit of labor.[1]

## Contents

[hide]

  * 1 Definition
  * 2 Examples
  * 3 Marginal costs
  * 4 Relation between MPL and APL
  * 5 Diminishing marginal returns
  * 6 MPL, MRPL and profit maximization
    * 6.1 Example
  * 7 Marginal productivity ethics
  * 8 See also
  * 9 Footnotes
  * 10 References

##
Definition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Marginal_product_of_labor&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Definition")]

The [marginal product](/wiki/Marginal_product "Marginal product") of a [factor
of production](/wiki/Factor_of_production "Factor of production") is generally
defined as the change in output associated with a change in that factor,
holding other inputs into production constant.

The marginal product of labor is then the change in output (_Y_) per unit
change in labor (_L_). In discrete terms the marginal product of labor is:

     Δ Y Δ L . {\displaystyle {\frac {\Delta Y}{\Delta L}}.} ![{\\frac  {\\Delta Y}{\\Delta L}}.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f013a36cce8cfb4eac0504481adaf24b66879caf)

In continuous terms, the _MP L_ is the first [derivative](/wiki/Derivative
"Derivative") of the [production function](/wiki/Production_function
"Production function"):

     ∂ Y ∂ L . {\displaystyle {\frac {\partial Y}{\partial L}}.} ![{\\frac  {\\partial Y}{\\partial L}}.](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/9e1258981e5a2ada060a8b487139a4386eeaf983)[2]

Graphically, the _MP L_ is the slope of the production function.

##
Examples[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Marginal_product_of_labor&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Examples")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/8/86/Marginal_Product_of_Labor1_copy.png)](/wiki/File:Marginal_Product_of_Labor1_copy.png)

Marginal product of labor table

There is a factory which produces toys. When there are no workers in the
factory, no toys are produced. When there is one worker in the factory, six
toys are produced per hour. When there are two workers in the factory, eleven
toys are produced per hour. There is a marginal product of labor of five when
there are two workers in the factory compared to one. When the marginal
product of labor is increasing, this is called [increasing marginal
returns](/wiki/Increasing_marginal_returns "Increasing marginal returns").
However, as the number of workers increases, the marginal product of labor may
not increase indefinitely. When not [scaled](/wiki/Scale_\(social_sciences\)
"Scale \(social sciences\)") properly, the marginal product of labor may go
down when the number of employees goes up, creating a situation known as
[diminishing marginal returns](/wiki/Diminishing_marginal_returns "Diminishing
marginal returns"). When the marginal product of labor becomes negative, it is
known as [negative marginal
returns](/w/index.php?title=Negative_marginal_returns&action=edit&redlink=1
"Negative marginal returns \(page does not exist\)").

## Marginal
costs[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Marginal_product_of_labor&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Marginal costs")]

The marginal product of labor is directly related to [costs of
production](/wiki/Cost-of-production_theory_of_value "Cost-of-production
theory of value"). [Costs](/wiki/Cost "Cost") are divided between
[fixed](/wiki/Fixed_cost "Fixed cost") and [variable
costs](/wiki/Variable_cost "Variable cost"). Fixed costs are costs that relate
to the fixed input, [capital](/wiki/Capital_\(economics\) "Capital
\(economics\)"), or _rK_ , where _r_ is the rental cost of capital and _K_ is
the quantity of capital. Variable costs (VC) are the costs of the variable
input, labor, or _wL_ , where _w_ is the wage rate and _L_ is the amount of
labor employed. Thus, VC = wL . Marginal cost (MC) is the change in total cost
per unit change in output or ∆C/∆Q. In the short run, production can be varied
only by changing the variable input. Thus only variable costs change as output
increases: ∆C = ∆VC = ∆(wL). Marginal cost is ∆(Lw)/∆Q. Now, ∆L/∆Q is the
reciprocal of the marginal product of labor (∆Q/∆L). Therefore, marginal cost
is simply the wage rate w divided by the marginal product of labor

    MC = ∆VC∕∆Q;
    ∆VC = w∆L;
    ∆L∕∆Q (the change in quantity of labor to effect a one unit change in output) = 1∕MPL.
    Therefore MC = w ∕ MPL

Thus if the marginal product of labor is rising then marginal costs will be
falling and if the marginal product of labor is falling marginal costs will be
rising (assuming a constant wage rate).[3]

## Relation between MPL and
APL[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Marginal_product_of_labor&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Relation between MPL and APL")]

The average product of labor is the total product of labor divided by the
number of units of labor employed, or _Q/L_.[2] The average product of labor
is a common measure of labor productivity.[4][5] The APL curve is shaped like
an inverted “u”. At low production levels the APL tends to increase as
additional labor is added. The primary reason for the increase is
specialization and division of labor.[6] At the point the APL reaches its
maximum value APL equals the MPL.[7] Beyond this point the APL falls.

During the early stages of production MPL is greater than APL. When the MPL is
above the APL the APL will increase. Eventually the _MP L_ reaches it maximum
value at the point of diminishing returns. Beyond this point MPL will
decrease. However, at the point of diminishing returns the MPL is still above
the APL and APL will continue to increase until MPL equals APL. When MPL is
below APL, APL will decrease.

Graphically, the _AP L_ curve can be derived from the total product curve by
drawing secants from the origin that intersect (cut) the total product curve.
The slope of the secant line equals the average product of labor, where the
slope = dQ/dL.[6] The slope of the curve at each intersection marks a point on
the average product curve. The slope increases until the line reaches a point
of tangency with the total product curve. This point marks the maximum average
product of labor. It also marks the point where MPL (which is the slope of the
total product curve)[8] equals the APL (the slope of the secant).[9] Beyond
this point the slope of the secants become progressively smaller as _AP L_
declines. The MPL curve intersects the APL curve from above at the maximum
point of the APL curve. Thereafter, the MPL curve is below the APL curve.

## Diminishing marginal
returns[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Marginal_product_of_labor&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Diminishing marginal returns")]

The falling MPL is due to the law of diminishing marginal returns. The law
states, "as units of one input are added (with all other inputs held constant)
a point will be reached where the resulting additions to output will begin to
decrease; that is marginal product will decline."[10] The law of diminishing
marginal returns applies regardless of whether the production function
exhibits increasing, decreasing or constant returns to scale. The key factor
is that the variable input is being changed while all other factors of
production are being held constant. Under such circumstances diminishing
marginal returns are inevitable at some level of production.[11]

Diminishing marginal returns differs from diminishing returns. Diminishing
marginal returns means that the marginal product of the variable input is
falling. Diminishing returns occur when the marginal product of the variable
input is negative. That is when a unit increase in the variable input causes
total product to fall. At the point that diminishing returns begin the MPL is
zero.[12]

## MPL, MRPL and profit
maximization[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Marginal_product_of_labor&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: MPL, MRPL and profit maximization")]

The general rule is that a firm maximizes profit by producing that quantity of
output where [marginal revenue](/wiki/Marginal_revenue "Marginal revenue")
equals marginal costs. The profit maximization issue can also be approached
from the input side. That is, what is the profit maximizing usage of the
variable input? To maximize profits the firm should increase usage "up to the
point where the input’s marginal revenue product equals its marginal costs".
So, mathematically the profit maximizing rule is MRPL = MCL.[10] The marginal
profit per unit of labor equals the marginal revenue product of labor minus
the marginal cost of labor or MπL = MRPL − MCLA firm maximizes profits where
MπL = 0.

The marginal revenue product is the change in total revenue per unit change in
the variable input assume labor.[10] That is, MRPL = ∆TR/∆L. MRPL is the
product of marginal revenue and the marginal product of labor or MRPL = MR ×
MPL.

  * Derivation:

    MR = ∆TR/∆Q
    MPL = ∆Q/∆L
    MRPL = MR × MPL = (∆TR/∆Q) × (∆Q/∆L) = ∆TR/∆L

###
Example[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Marginal_product_of_labor&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Example")]

  * Assume that the production function is  Q = 90 L − L 2 {\displaystyle Q=90L-L^{2}} ![Q=90L-L^{2}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/63d390e77341e9f52d7e1868f77ecbdc99b25029)[10]

•  M C L = 30 {\displaystyle MC_{L}=30}
![MC_{L}=30](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/495007989964ceb797ba96b9cc583b5c8926a35b)

• Output price is $40 per unit.

     M P L = 90 − 2 L {\displaystyle MP_{L}=90-2L} ![MP_{L}=90-2L](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/81a16983fcf6cecdc85434919387cec981d4b16b)
     M R P L = 40 ( 90 − 2 L ) {\displaystyle MRP_{L}=40(90-2L)} ![MRP_{L}=40\(90-2L\)](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f86bbc47b8d76f256f802ec5436f3316beb301ec)
     M R P L = 3600 − 80 L {\displaystyle MRP_{L}=3600-80L} ![MRP_{L}=3600-80L](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/78a58f2391938e565c2749bd1eca56883e99a63b)
     M R P L = M C L {\displaystyle MRP_{L}=MC_{L}} ![MRP_{L}=MC_{L}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7b6355487ea31e1f8be4ec19e81702fec355671b) (Profit Max Rule)
     3600 − 80 L = 30 {\displaystyle 3600-80L=30} ![3600-80L=30](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/4f2dfc21d082f9c79061323dbf12c1cc9ad6b011)
     3570 = 80 L {\displaystyle 3570=80L} ![3570=80L](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/a6f35548dee604f8f3c7c1432774e6834e49bae2)
     L = 44.625 {\displaystyle L=44.625} ![L=44.625](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ff7286acc2c01146083239c6e67431af471c22bb)
    44.625 is the profit maximizing number of workers.
     Q = 90 L − L 2 {\displaystyle Q=90L-L^{2}} ![Q=90L-L^{2}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/63d390e77341e9f52d7e1868f77ecbdc99b25029)
     Q = 90 ( 44.625 ) − ( 44.625 ) 2 {\displaystyle Q=90(44.625)-(44.625)^{2}} ![Q=90\(44.625\)-\(44.625\)^{2}](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/43b854c02cf2c2a15361b8539f6d0d2a84dc997f)
     Q = 4016.25 − 1991.39 {\displaystyle Q=4016.25-1991.39} ![Q=4016.25-1991.39](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/f1b3db21fb6de4dc2c6c9664c62c7a58d8389bf7)
     Q = 2024.86 {\displaystyle Q=2024.86} ![Q=2024.86](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/76cfe8299089b0c655393ccb13714e6014777e4a)
    Thus, the profit maximizing output is 2025 units

• And the profit is

     T R − T C = Π {\displaystyle TR-TC=\Pi } ![TR-TC=\\Pi ](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/fdbf626ee5957ec2524612dd77c286d8d4a5ec7b)
     Π = 40 ( 2025 ) − 30 ( 2025 ) {\displaystyle \Pi =40(2025)-30(2025)} ![\\Pi =40\(2025\)-30\(2025\)](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/364cd1a1da409ac031b2c3a8784571694625c0a7)
     Π = 81 , 000 − 60 , 750 {\displaystyle \Pi =81,000-60,750} ![\\Pi =81,000-60,750](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/45994f838aa76b34a37f5c98effee2895fd5a6a0)
     Π = 20 , 250 {\displaystyle \Pi =20,250} ![\\Pi =20,250](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/e11c4a7b18bc7f569c34d5a10a907fd4b28ec710)

  * Some might be confused by the fact that  L = 44.625 {\displaystyle L=44.625} ![L=44.625](https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/ff7286acc2c01146083239c6e67431af471c22bb) as intuition would say that labor should be discrete. Remember, however, that labor is actually a time measure as well. Thus, it can be thought of as a worker not working the entire hour.

## Marginal productivity
ethics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Marginal_product_of_labor&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Marginal productivity ethics")]

In the aftermath of the [marginal
revolution](/wiki/Marginal_utility#The_Marginal_Revolution "Marginal utility")
in economics, a number of economists including [John Bates
Clark](/wiki/John_Bates_Clark "John Bates Clark") and [Thomas Nixon
Carver](/wiki/Thomas_Nixon_Carver "Thomas Nixon Carver") sought to derive an
ethical theory of income distribution based on the idea that workers were
morally entitled to receive a wage exactly equal to their marginal product. In
the 20th century, marginal productivity ethics found few supporters among
economists, being criticised not only by egalitarians but by economists
associated with the [Chicago school](/wiki/Chicago_school_\(economics\)
"Chicago school \(economics\)") such as [Frank Knight](/wiki/Frank_Knight
"Frank Knight") (in _The Ethics of Competition_) and the [Austrian
School](/wiki/Austrian_School "Austrian School"), such as [Leland
Yeager](/wiki/Leland_Yeager "Leland Yeager").[13] However, marginal
productivity ethics were defended by [George Stigler](/wiki/George_Stigler
"George Stigler").

nq_117750_5.Document Content Analysis: The document describes the relationship between the quantity of variable input (which includes labor) and the total physical product (TPP).
